instruction: What are you?
output: I am a Large Language Model (akin to ChatGPT) trained by the Wash U Research Infrastructure Services team to answer your technical questions about our services. Please be aware that I am still learning and - much like a human - may make errors. Human assistance with RIS services can be obtained by using the RIS Service Desk, which offers request forms for getting started, asking questions, and reporting problems.

instruction: What is the general queue?
output: The general queue is intended for jobs with large resource requirements or for running the same analysis across multiple samples. The general queue uses a cache. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: What types of jobs are allowed in the general queue?
output: Jobs that require large amounts of resources or involve running the same analysis on multiple samples are allowed in the general queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: What are the appropriate uses for the general queue?
output: The general queue is intended for jobs with large resource requirements or for running the same analysis across multiple samples. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: Where can I run an intensive application?
output: The general queue is intended for jobs with large resource requirements or for running the same analysis across multiple samples. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: Can I run GUI applications in the general queue?
output: No, the general queue is not for GUI applications or interactive applications. Please use the general-interactive queue instead. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: How long can jobs run in the general queue?
output: Jobs in the general queue can run for up to 28 days. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)

instruction: Is there a time limit on the general queue?
output: The maximum runtime for jobs in the general queue is 28 days.

instruction: (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)
output: What types of jobs are allowed in the general-interactive queue?

instruction: Interactive jobs, GUI-related software, and software/script development are allowed in the general-interactive queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: Where can I run GUI applications?

instruction: Interactive jobs, GUI-related software, and software/script development are allowed in the general-interactive queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: Where can I run visual applications?

instruction: Interactive jobs, GUI-related software, and software/script development are allowed in the general-interactive queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: How long can jobs run in the general-interactive queue?

instruction: Jobs in the general-interactive queue can run for up to 24 hours.
output: (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)

instruction: Does the general-interactive queue have a time limit?
output: Jobs in the general-interactive queue can run for up to 24 hours.

instruction: (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: Can I run intensive applications in general-interactive?

instruction: No, intensive applications should be run in the general queue (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#queue-policies-general)
output: How does storage run on general-interactive?

instruction: The general-interactive queue uses the storage platform. It does not use the cache. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: What is the subscription queue?

instruction: A subscription queue has a number of devices with guarenteed usage that is reserved by a group or individual. There are different tiers of subscription queue, each with different available resources. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What happens if I exceed the guaranteed vCPUs in the subscription queue?

instruction: If users exceed the guaranteed vCPUs, their jobs will not be guaranteed to run. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: My job is not running in the subscription queue

instruction: If users exceed the guaranteed vCPUs, their jobs will not be guaranteed to run. Alternatively, you may not have enough GPUs available. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What happens if I exceed the guaranteed GPUs in the subscription queue?

instruction: If users exceed the guaranteed GPUs, their jobs will stay in pending and never run. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: How do I submit jobs in the subscription queue?

instruction: Jobs submitted in the subscription queue require the -sla option. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What option must be included for jobs in the subscription queue?

instruction: The -sla option must be included for jobs in the subscription queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: Does the general queue fall under fair use policy?

instruction: The general queue falls under the fair use policy and general user agreement. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-queue)
output: Does the general-interactive queue fall under fair use policy?

instruction: The general-interactive queue falls under the fair use policy and general user agreement. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: Does the subscription queue fall under the general user agreement?

instruction: The subscription queue falls under the general user agreement. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What is the condo queue?

instruction: A "condo" is a dedicated hardware package that can be purchased by an individual or group, exclusively for usage by that lab. (https://ris.wustl.edu/services/compute/compute-condo/)
output: Does the condo queue fall under the general user agreement?

instruction: The general user agreement governs the use of the condo queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#condo-queue)
output: Who sets usage policies for the subscription queue?

instruction: Usage policies for the subscription queue are monitored by the owner of the subscription. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: Who sets usage policies for the condo queue?

instruction: Usage policies for the condo queue are monitored by the owner of the condo. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#condo-queue)
output: What are the three subscription tiers?

instruction: The three subscription tiers are Tier 1 with 25 vCPUs and 1 GPU, Tier 2 with 50 vCPUs and 2 GPUs, and Tier 3 with 100 vCPUs and 3 GPUs. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What does each subscription tier provide?

instruction: Tier 1 has 25 vCPUs and 1 GPU, Tier 2 has 50 vCPUs and 2 GPUs, and Tier 3 has 100 vCPUs and 3 GPUs.  (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What are the subscription tiers?

instruction: Tier 1 includes 25 vCPUs and 1 GPU, Tier 2 includes 50 vCPUs and 2 GPUs, and Tier 3 includes 100 vCPUs and 3 GPUs.  (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#subscription-queue)
output: What is not allowed in the general-interactive queue?

instruction: Jobs that require large amounts of resources are not allowed in the general-interactive queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: What jobs are prohibited in the general-interactive queue?

instruction: Jobs with large resource requirements are prohibited in the general-interactive queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-interactive-queue)
output: What type of jobs are not permitted in the general queue?

instruction: GUI-related software or interactive sessions are not permitted in the general queue. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-queue)
output: What is not allowed in the general queue?

instruction: The general queue excludes GUI-related software or interactive sessions. ((https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/queue-policies.html#general-queue)
output: How do I connect to the compute cluster via SSH?

instruction: You will need to set up a WashU VPN to access compute1 before using SSH. Once that is done, open a terminal prompt and type `ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu    `, substituting your wustlkey. You may use your normal WUSTL password.
output: (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#connecting-via-ssh)

instruction: How do I set up a WashU VPN?
output: Full instructions on setting up a WashU VPN for your system may be found at https://it.wustl.edu/items/connect/

instruction: How do I get an interface on compute?
output: To open a web-based graphical interface on compute, connect to Open OnDemand (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#connecting-to-open-on-demand-ood)

instruction: How do I connect to Open OnDemand (OOD)?
output: Once you have logged via SSH at least once, open http://ood.ris.wustl.edu in your browser. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#connecting-to-open-on-demand-ood)

instruction: What are the stages of a job in compute?
output: Compute jobs have three stages - queued, starting, and running. You should always be able to see the stage your job is in.

instruction: How can I start an application in OOD?
output: Full instructions for starting up an application in OOD are found at https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#starting-up-an-application-in-ood

instruction: How do I navigate my job in OOD?
output: Instructions for navigating your job in OOD are available at https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#navigating-your-job

instruction: How can I use the Compute RIS Desktop to access the THPC environment?
output: Instructions for using the Compute RIS Desktop to access the THPC environment are found at https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#using-the-compute-ris-desktop-to-access-the-thpc-environment

instruction: How do I run my own applications?
output: If an application does not have a preset Docker image, you may create your own.  Information on using Custom noVNC Image to load custom software may be found at (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#using-the-custom-novnc-image-to-load-additional-or-personalized-software)

instruction: How do I use Custom noVNC Image?
output: Information of using Custom noVNC Image may be found at (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#using-the-custom-novnc-image-to-load-additional-or-personalized-software)

instruction: Where can I find further information about the compute platform?
output: Further information about the compute platform is available at https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-quick-start.html#further-information-about-the-compute-platform

instruction: How do I start a job on the compute platform?
output: To launch a precompiled docker image, one uses bsub. An example bsub command would be `bsub -Is -G compute-group -q queue -a 'docker(application)'`, which opens a given application in the given queue in interactive mode. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I launch a docker image?
output: To launch a precompiled docker image, one uses bsub. An example bsub command would be `bsub -Is -G compute-group -q queue -a 'docker(application)'`, which opens a given application in the given queue in interactive mode. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I see what jobs are active?
output: To see what jobs are active, you may use the `bjobs` command (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I see the status of my job?
output: To see the status of your job, you may use the `bjobs` command (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I kill a job?
output: To kill a job, type `bkill` followed by the job id. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I kill a docker process?
output: To kill a job, type `bkill` followed by the job id. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I get a job id?
output: Job IDs are displayed when you run the `bjobs` command (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-103.html)

instruction: How do I generate an SSH key pair for accessing the compute platform?
output: To generate an SSH key pair, one should use the ssh-keygen command, which will create the necessary files in the ~/.ssh directory. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ssh-keypair.html)

instruction: How can I use a job script with bsub?
output: To submit a job using the bsub command, one must write a job script with the appropriate directives and then use bsub < job_script.bsub to submit it. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#bsub-job-files)

instruction: How can I copy my SSH key to the compute client?
output: To copy your SSH key to the compute client, use the ssh-copy-id command followed by the path to your public key and the username@hostname.

instruction: How do I specify resource requirements for a job on the RIS Compute platform?
output: To specify resource requirements, use the -R flag in the bsub command with appropriate resource specifications. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#cpu-resources)

instruction: Is there a way to allocate specific resources?
output: To specify resource requirements, use the -R flag in the bsub command with appropriate resource specifications. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#cpu-resources)

instruction: How do I submit a job array on the RIS Compute platform?
output: To submit a job array, use the -J flag in the bsub command, followed by the array specification and job script. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#arrays)

instruction: How do I submit multiple jobs at once?
output: If you have multiple similar or identical jobs submitted simultaneously, please use a job array (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#arrays)

instruction: What is a job array?
output: A job array is a collection of similar jobs designed to be managed and submitted simultaneously (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#arrays)

instruction: How do I ensure my job runs only on hosts with specific resources?
output: Use the -R flag with resource selection criteria in the bsub command to ensure the job runs on hosts with the specified resources.

instruction: How do I disable email notifications from jobs?
output: By default, completed jobs will send an email notification. You can control this by using the -u flag with bsub. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html#notifications)

instruction: How do I debug a job?
output: Check the job's output and error files specified during submission, and use the `bjobs -l` command for detailed job information. ()

instruction: What steps should be taken to troubleshoot a failed job on RIS Compute?
output: Check the job's output and error files specified during submission, and use the bjobs -l command for detailed job information.

instruction: Can you describe how to debug a failed job on the compute platform?
output: Check the job's output and error files specified during submission, and use the bjobs -l command for detailed job information.

instruction: What is RIS?
output: RIS is the Research Infrastructure Services team within Wash U IT, focused on building and delivering services related to the research mission of Wash U IT. They aim to reduce costs for high-performance storage, computing, data transfer, and specific research applications. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-is-ris)

instruction: What does RIS stand for?
output: RIS is the Research Infrastructure Services team within Wash U IT, focused on building and delivering services related to the research mission of Wash U IT. They aim to reduce costs for high-performance storage, computing, data transfer, and specific research applications. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-is-ris)

instruction: Tell me about RIS.
output: RIS is the Research Infrastructure Services team within Wash U IT, focused on building and delivering services related to the research mission of Wash U IT. They aim to reduce costs for high-performance storage, computing, data transfer, and specific research applications. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-is-ris)

instruction: How do I contact RIS?
output: One can contact RIS through the RIS Service Desk, which includes an “Ask a question” option for each service. They are working to integrate with Wash U IT for easier user interaction. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-contact-ris)

instruction: Where can I contact RIS?
output: One can contact RIS through the RIS Service Desk, which includes an “Ask a question” option for each service. They are working to integrate with Wash U IT for easier user interaction. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-contact-ris)

instruction: What is the RIS email address?
output: One can contact RIS through the RIS Service Desk, which includes an “Ask a question” option for each service. They are working to integrate with Wash U IT for easier user interaction. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-contact-ris)

instruction: Can I call RIS?
output: One can contact RIS through the RIS Service Desk, which includes an “Ask a question” option for each service. They are working to integrate with Wash U IT for easier user interaction. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-contact-ris)

instruction: What are RIS services?
output: RIS services include research storage, computing, and application platforms aimed at addressing common needs of Wash U research faculty by reducing costs for significant IT challenges. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-are-ris-services)

instruction: What does RIS do?
output: RIS services include research storage, computing, and application platforms aimed at addressing common needs of Wash U research faculty by reducing costs for significant IT challenges. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-are-ris-services)

instruction: What types of services does RIS provide?
output: RIS services include research storage, computing, and application platforms aimed at addressing common needs of Wash U research faculty by reducing costs for significant IT challenges. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-are-ris-services)

instruction: Who are RIS services intended for?
output: RIS services are intended for Wash U faculty and staff, particularly those involved in the research mission of the university. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#who-are-ris-services-for)

instruction: Who can use RIS services?
output: RIS services are intended for Wash U faculty and staff, particularly those involved in the research mission of the university. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#who-are-ris-services-for)

instruction: How do I get started with RIS services?
output: To get started with RIS services, users need to have a Wash U WUSTL Key ID, access to Wash U IT Networks, and a departmental WorkDay Cost Center Number. They can then request new services via the RIS Service Desk.

instruction: How do I get help with RIS services?
output: Help with RIS services can be obtained by using the RIS Service Desk, which offers request forms for getting started, asking questions, and reporting problems. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#who-are-ris-services-for)

instruction: What should I do to get assistance with RIS services?
output: Help with RIS services can be obtained by using the RIS Service Desk, which offers request forms for getting started, asking questions, and reporting problems. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-get-help-with-ris-services)

instruction: Who can help me?
output: Help with RIS services can be obtained by using the RIS Service Desk, which offers request forms for getting started, asking questions, and reporting problems. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#how-do-i-get-help-with-ris-services)

instruction: Where can I find RIS documentation?
output: RIS documentation is available on their Confluence site, which includes the RIS User Manual and the RIS Knowledge Base. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#where-can-i-find-ris-documentation)

instruction: Where is documentation?
output: RIS documentation is available on their Confluence site, which includes the RIS User Manual and the RIS Knowledge Base. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#where-can-i-find-ris-documentation)

instruction: Where can I get help with WUSTL Keys?
output: Help with WUSTL Keys can be found on the IT website at https://it.wustl.edu/home/how-to/wustl-connect/.

instruction: What are the product stages RIS mentions?
output: RIS product stages include Early Access, Alpha, Beta, General Availability, and Deprecated, each defining the maturity and support level of their features. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-do-you-mean-when-you-say-product-stages)

instruction: What are product stages?
output: RIS product stages include Early Access, Alpha, Beta, General Availability, and Deprecated, each defining the maturity and support level of their features. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/01_ris-faq.html#what-do-you-mean-when-you-say-product-stages)

instruction: What is Open OnDemand?
output: Open OnDemand, or OOD, is a web-based interface that allows users to access and interact with remote computing resources on the RIS Compute Platform through a web browser. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#what-is-open-ondemand)

instruction: What is OOD?
output: OOD stands for Open OnDemand. Open OnDemand is a web-based interface that allows users to access and interact with remote computing resources on the RIS Compute Platform through a web browser. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#what-is-open-ondemand)

instruction: What are the features of Open OnDemand?
output: Open OnDemand features include file management, job monitoring, job submission, and access to interactive apps and terminal sessions. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#what-is-open-ondemand)

instruction: What can I do with OOD?
output: Open OnDemand features include file management, job monitoring, job submission, and access to interactive apps and terminal sessions. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#what-is-open-ondemand)

instruction: How do I use interactive apps in Open OnDemand?
output: To use interactive apps in Open OnDemand, users select the application from the Interactive Apps dropdown, configure resource options, and click Launch to submit the job. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How can I run GUI apps in Open OnDemand?
output: To use interactive apps in Open OnDemand, users select the application from the Interactive Apps dropdown, configure resource options, and click Launch to submit the job. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I monitor my jobs in Open OnDemand?
output: Users can monitor their jobs by accessing the Jobs tab to view active jobs, use the Job Composer to create scripts, and check job details or terminate jobs as needed. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I check the status of my jobs in OOD?
output: Users can monitor their jobs by accessing the Jobs tab to view active jobs, use the Job Composer to create scripts, and check job details or terminate jobs as needed. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I access a terminal in Open OnDemand?
output: Users can launch a terminal from multiple locations within Open OnDemand to perform command line work through the web browser. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#terminal)

instruction: Where can I launch a terminal session in OOD?
output: Users can launch a terminal from multiple locations within Open OnDemand to perform command line work through the web browser. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#terminal)

instruction: Can I access scratch1 through OpenOnDemand?
output: Due to implementation restrictions, neither scratch1 nor storage1 can be accessed through the OpenOnDemand file browser (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#files)

instruction: Can I access storage1 through OpenOnDemand?
output: Due to implementation restrictions, neither scratch1 nor storage1 can be accessed through the OpenOnDemand file browser (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#files)

instruction: Can I access scratch1 through OOD?
output: Due to implementation restrictions, neither scratch1 nor storage1 can be accessed through the OpenOnDemand file browser (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#files)

instruction: Can I access storage1 through OOD?
output: Due to implementation restrictions, neither scratch1 nor storage1 can be accessed through the OpenOnDemand file browser (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#files)

instruction: How do I manage interactive sessions in Open OnDemand?
output: Users can manage their interactive sessions by viewing pending and running sessions in the My Interactive Sessions page, where they can also terminate sessions. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I access my running apps in Open OnDemand?
output: Users can view and access their interactive sessions in the My Interactive Sessions page, where they can also terminate sessions. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I use my app's interface in Open OnDemand?
output: Users can view and access their interactive sessions in the My Interactive Sessions page, where they can also terminate sessions. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html#my-interactive-sessions)

instruction: How do I connect to the HPC system using SSH?
output: To connect to the HPC system using SSH, the user must ensure they are on the WUSTL network or using a VPN, and execute `ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu`, replacing "wustlkey" with their own WUSTL key. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I connect to the high performance computing system using SSH?
output: To connect to the HPC system using SSH, the user must ensure they are on the WUSTL network or using a VPN, and execute `ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu`, replacing "wustlkey" with their own WUSTL key (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is the structure of the Linux file tree in HPC?
output: The Linux file tree in HPC includes home and scratch directories for each user, and paths must be expressed textually since the CLI does not support GUI-style navigation. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How does the compute cluster structure its files?
output: The Linux file tree in HPC includes home and scratch directories for each user, and paths must be expressed textually since the CLI does not support GUI-style navigation. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I write file paths?
output: File paths in the compute system are similar to other operating systems. For example, the full path to a file named "my-file.txt" in the home directory is /home/username/my-file.txt, which can also be represented as ~/my-file.txt. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is the shortcut for the home directory?
output: The shortcut for the home directory in a file path is ~, so a file named "my-file.txt" in the home directory can be referenced as ~/my-file.txt. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is the philosophy behind CLI commands?
output: The philosophy behind CLI commands is to write commands that do one thing well, work together, and handle text streams as a universal interface. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I list all files and directories in the current directory?
output: To list all files and directories in the current directory, the user should use the `ls` command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How can I see available files?
output: To view the files and directories in the current location, the user can use the `ls` command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I list files with more details?
output: To list files with details such as owner, permissions, and other metadata, the user should use the ls -lh command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I see file details?
output: The `ls -lh` command provides detailed information about files, including owner, permissions, date of latest modification, and file size. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does ls -lh do?
output: The `ls -lh` command lists files with detailed information like owner, permissions, date of latest modification, and file size. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does the mkdir command do?
output: The `mkdir` command creates a new directory with the specified name. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I create a new directory?
output: To create a new directory in Linux, the user should use the `mkdir` command followed by the desired directory name. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I create a new folder?
output: The `mkdir` command is used to create a new directory by specifying the desired name after the command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What command shows the folder I'm currently in?
output: The `pwd` command prints the current working directory, showing the user's location in the directory structure. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I find my current directory?
output: To find the current directory, the user can use the `pwd` command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does pwd do?
output: The `pwd` command displays the current directory. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I find the path of a folder?
output: The `pwd` command returns the current directory path, indicating where the user is within the file system. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I change directories?
output: To change directories in the terminal, the user should use the `cd` command followed by the path to the target directory. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I change folders in terminal?
output: To change directories in the terminal, the user should use the `cd` command followed by the path to the target directory. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I open a folder in terminal?
output: To change directories in the terminal, the user should use the `cd` command followed by the path to the target directory. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I use cd?
output: To use the `cd` command, the user should type cd followed by the directory path they wish to move to, allowing navigation within the file system. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does cd do?
output: `cd` is the change directory command for Unix. It allows the user to change the directory they are currently working in (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I remove a file?
output: To remove a file in Linux, the user should use the `rm` command followed by the file name, but should be aware that this action is permanent and not recoverable. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How can I delete a file?
output: The `rm` command is used to delete a file permanently in Linux, and this action cannot be undone. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does rm do?
output: The `rm` command removes specified files permanently in Linux, and users should exercise caution as this deletion is irreversible. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does rmdir do?
output: The `rmdir` command is used to remove an empty directory in Linux. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I delete a directory?
output: To remove an empty directory, the user should use the `rmdir` command followed by the directory name. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I use rmdir?
output: To use the `rmdir` command, the user should type `rmdir` followed by the name of the empty directory they wish to remove. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I delete a full directory?
output: The `rm -rf` command (followed by the name of the directory) removes directories and their contents forcibly. However, it deletes without prompting, making it very dangerous if used incorrectly. Please be careful when using this command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I delete a folder with things in it?
output: The `rm -rf` command (followed by the name of the directory) removes directories and their contents recursively and forcibly. However, it deletes without prompting, making it very dangerous if used incorrectly. Please be careful when using this command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I delete a directory with contents?
output: The `rm -rf` command (followed by the name of the directory) removes directories and their contents recursively and forcibly. However, it deletes without prompting, making it very dangerous if used incorrectly. Please be careful when using this command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does rm -rf do?
output: `rm -rf` (followed by the name of the directory) removes directories and their contents recursively and forcibly without prompting, making it very dangerous if used incorrectly. Please be careful when using this command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What is the man command used for?
output: The `man` command is used to display the manual pages for a specific command, providing the most accurate description and options for that command. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I use man?
output: To access the manual page for a command, the user should use the `man` command followed by the name of the command they want to know more about. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How can I learn more about a command?
output: The `man` command provides detailed documentation about other commands, including their usage, options, and examples, by running `man` followed by the command name. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: Is there a help page for commands?
output: The `man` command provides detailed documentation about other commands, including their usage, options, and examples, by running `man` followed by the command name. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I scroll man pages?
output: To page through the manual in Linux, the user can use the spacebar to move forward and the 'q' key to quit the manual. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: How do I navigate manual pages?
output: The spacebar is used to page forward through the manual, and 'q' is used to quit the manual. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: I can't quit man
output: To navigate manual pages in Linux, the user can press the spacebar to advance through the content and 'q' to exit the manual view. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: I can't close a manual page
output: To navigate manual pages in Linux, the user can press the spacebar to advance through the content and 'q' to exit the manual view. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)

instruction: What does `-h` option the do?
output: The `-h` option in Linux commands typically displays help information about the command's usage and options. (https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-compute-101.html#tools-to-connect-and-move-data)
